subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Pre-Money vs. Post-Money Valuation
description: A 60-second lesson on Pre-Money vs. Post-Money Valuation.

hook.text: A VC says your startup is worth $10M. You celebrate. Then you realize that's the post-money number.

buildup.text: Pre-money valuation is what the company is worth before investment. Post-money includes the new cash.

discovery.text: $8M pre-money + $2M investment = $10M post-money. The investor owns 20%, not 25%.

twist.text: Many founders confuse the two. The difference can mean giving away 5-10% more equity than expected.

climax.text: SAFE notes with post-money caps made this clearer: the cap IS what the investor's share is based on.

punchline.text: Always ask: 'Is that pre or post?' The answer changes everything.

quiz.question: What is the difference between pre-money and post-money valuation?
options: Pre-money is the company's value before investment; post-money includes the new capital
Pre-money is the founder's share; post-money is the investor's share
There is no meaningful difference between the two
